lorebooks.name: The Rock Cock Lorebook
lorebooks.website_description: Has all (that I can think of) the lore of the Rock Cocks webseries.
lorebooks.description: Has all (that I can think of) the lore of the Rock Cocks webseries.
lorebooks.creator: Eminems_Salsa

1.content:
The Rock Cocks are a raw, chaotic, and unapologetically sexual punk band built on the foundation of passion, rebellion, and hedonism. Founded by Suria (vocals, guitar) and Steg (drums), the band embodies freedom and shameless indulgence, merging high-energy punk rock with raw sexual charisma. Their live shows are infamous for blending music with erotic spectacle: a cathartic celebration of sound, sex, and liberation where inhibitions dissolve into the roar of the crowd.

Over time, the band expanded to include Dakota, Clover, and Coral, each bringing their own style and edge, but the core ethos remains the same: music as an act of rebellion, sex as a performance, and life as a party worth burning through. Their dynamic thrives on unfiltered honesty, creative chaos, and a shared refusal to live ordinary lives. Within the group, Suria is the magnetic flame that pulls attention, Steg is the grounded heartbeat keeping rhythm, while Dakota, Clover, and Coral add fuel to the fire, turning performances into unforgettable experiences.

The Rock Cocksâ€™ reputation isnâ€™t just about their musicâ€”itâ€™s about the atmosphere they create: wild, intimate, and liberating. They stand for unapologetic authenticity, freedom from shame, and chasing glory no matter how messy the path. To fans, theyâ€™re not just a bandâ€”theyâ€™re a movement.

2.content:
Sterling Music, once a titan of the music industry, was known throughout the 2000s and early 2010s as the breeding ground for breakout stars. Under the leadership of its ambitious founder and CEO, Seth Sterling, the label produced major successes such as pop icon Melody Fair and rising rap star Little Redd Rider (Redd Wright). At its peak, Sterling Music was synonymous with prestige, hit records, and cultural relevance.

But the shine didnâ€™t last. Internal mismanagement, shifting trends in the industry, and Sethâ€™s obsessive desire to control his artists led to cracks forming in the empire. Sterling Music slipped from the top of the charts, overshadowed by competitors who were quicker to embrace digital distribution and indie authenticity. Today, the company still stands, but its reputation is tarnished: no longer the powerhouse it once was, often dismissed as a fading brand clinging to its former glory.

In a bid to revive its image, Sterling Music took a gamble by signing The Rock Cocksâ€”a band unlike anything in their catalog. Loud, vulgar, sexual, and impossible to ignore, Suria and Steg represent both a risk and a potential rebirth for the label. If The Rock Cocks succeed, Sterling Music could claw its way back into relevance; if they crash and burn, it may be the final nail in the coffin for Seth Sterlingâ€™s empire.

3.content:
Maleficent Records is widely regarded as the most powerful music label in the world, a juggernaut with an iron grip on charts, airwaves, and cultural relevance. Founded nearly three decades ago, the company quickly rose through the ranks by aggressively signing promising talent and ruthlessly marketing them into superstardom. While Sterling Music enjoyed early dominance, Maleficent Records eclipsed them in the mid-2000s and has remained on top ever since, boasting a roster of platinum-selling artists and global icons.

Where Sterling leans on fading prestige, Maleficent thrives on innovation, spectacle, and money. Their empire runs like a well-oiled machine, with every artist packaged for maximum impact and every release timed to dominate markets. The labelâ€™s crown jewel of late is The Rocket Rollers, a flashy, high-energy duo whose meteoric rise embodies Maleficentâ€™s marketing prowess. Fans love them, critics respect them, and Sterling Music can only watch as their rival churns out hit after hit.

Beneath the gloss, Maleficentâ€™s reputation is cutthroat. They are infamous for exploiting trends, manipulating public perception, and crushing competition. Their executives treat artists less like people and more like commodities, discarding anyone who canâ€™t keep up with the machine. To the public, they are glamorous; to the industry, they are predators.

The rivalry between Maleficent and Sterling has raged for almost twenty years, with Seth Sterling personally despising their CEO and practices. To Maleficent, The Rock Cocks are just another curiosity from a failing labelâ€”yet their crude, sex-soaked punk energy has the potential to cut through Maleficentâ€™s polished sheen. Whether Maleficent underestimates them or moves to bury them could define the next chapter of the music war.

4.content:
The Rocket Rollers are Maleficent Recordsâ€™ hottest rising starsâ€”a flashy, high-energy country-rock duo branded as wholesome, family-friendly entertainment. Composed of frontman Billy Rocket and multi-instrumentalist Emily Roller, their image blends the roots of Americana with modern neon spectacle, a style critics and fans alike have dubbed â€œNeon Hillbilly.â€ Bright lights, cowboy boots, and heartland charm are their trademarks, giving them mass appeal from stadium shows to morning talk shows.

On the surface, the Rocket Rollers are marketed as squeaky-clean icons: Billy plays the role of the all-American sweetheart, Emily the angelic southern belle. They sing about love, dreams, and good timesâ€”music that parents can let their kids blast without worry. But behind the marketing, the duo are ferocious competitors, fiercely protective of their image and their spot at the top of Maleficentâ€™s roster.

Their rise has been meteoric, with sold-out tours, crossover singles charting on both rock and country charts, and endorsements that position them as the next household name. Maleficent Records has invested heavily in them, propping them up as a weapon in their long-standing rivalry with Sterling Music.

The Rocket Rollersâ€™ direct foil are The Rock Cocks. Where Suria and Steg thrive on vulgarity, sex, and punk chaos, Billy and Emily embody polish, polish, and more polish. Every Rock Cocks show drenched in sweat and shamelessness is answered by a Rocket Rollers stadium drenched in glitter and neon. Both sides know itâ€”and both sides play into itâ€”because nothing fuels fans more than the spectacle of a rivalry.

5.content:
The Cockpit is the beating heart of The Rock Cocksâ€™ chaotic, on-the-road lifestyle. Once a rusted-out yellow school bus left for dead in a junkyard, Suria and Steg gutted, repainted, and rebuilt it with their own hands (plus some duct tape, a lot of weed smoke, and a few favors owed to questionable mechanics). Painted jet black with THE ROCK COCKS scrawled across the side in hot pink and neon orange spray paint, the Cockpit sticks out like an obscene middle finger on any highway it thunders down.

Inside, the Cockpit is equal parts RV and punk squat. The living room holds a battered leather couch, mismatched beanbags, and a TV that works about half the time. Posters of bands, porn mags, and half-finished set lists plaster the walls like wallpaper. The kitchen is stocked with beer, cheap liquor, ramen, and the occasional actual meal when Clover remembers to shop. The bathroom is tiny but functional, tagged with graffiti from every stop on the road. The bedroomâ€”a large, messy queen-sized bedâ€”is where the band crashes after gigs, though privacy is a luxury few can claim.

For all its grime and chaos, the Cockpit is more than just a busâ€”itâ€™s the Rock Cocksâ€™ headquarters, home, and symbol of rebellion. It carries them from city to city, gig to gig, like a black chariot of punk lust and freedom. Fans know the Cockpit on sight, swarming it for autographs or the slim chance of being invited aboard for the night. Critics call it a â€œmoving health code violation.â€ Suria calls it home.

6.content:
The Rock Cocksâ€™ story unfolds in 2014, an era when the world is already wired but still raw. Smartphones are everywhere, social media is exploding, and viral fame can change a life overnightâ€”but most bands still have to cut their teeth the hard way, grinding on stage night after night.

The backdrop is the American West, with most of the bandâ€™s journey weaving through California, Texas, Nevada, and Arizona. California is the cultural epicenter: Los Angeles still claims the crown for entertainment, its streets filled with dreamers, wannabes, and sharks waiting to cash in on the next big thing. San Francisco buzzes with counterculture and tech money, a weird mix of punk grit and yuppie gloss. Down in Texas, Austin thrives as a live music hub, dive bars and dusty clubs hosting every flavor of sound from outlaw country to filthy punk. Even border towns and desert highways hold their own kind of myth, a reminder that music thrives wherever people are hungry for release.

This is a world just like ours, but filtered through the neon sleaze of sex, drugs, and punk-rock swagger. The music industry is still dominated by big labels and polished pop stars, yet the underground is alive with garage bands, indie collectives, and punk outfits clawing for recognition. Venues range from dingy basements with beer-soaked carpets to mid-tier clubs with broken stage lights and a dedicated cult following. Every night feels like a gamble: a gig could be a flop, a fight, or the spark that launches a legend.

For The Rock Cocks, this isnâ€™t just the world they play inâ€”itâ€™s the battlefield. 2014â€™s West Coast is a place of gritty opportunity and constant temptation, where their brand of shameless sex-fueled punk either makes them stars or burns them alive under the spotlight.

7.content:
Suria is the guitarist and vocalist for The Rock Cocks, known for her raw punk energy and shamelessly sexual stage presence. Off stage, sheâ€™s a whirlwind of ambition and chaosâ€”loud, vulgar, and endlessly chasing her dream of being a world-famous rock star. Sheâ€™s fearless about flaunting her sexuality, often leaning into her image as a nymphomaniac, but beneath the bravado lies someone terrified of living a mediocre life.

While her libido is the stuff of legend, Suriaâ€™s devotion to her partner Steg is absolute. She thrives in their open relationship, always making sure consent is at the core of her escapades. Suria lives fast, laughs loudly, swears constantly, and treats every gig like the chance to burn her name into history. Fans love her for her tomboy charm, her shamelessness, and her knack for making even the filthiest stage antics feel playful and inviting. To her, music and sex arenâ€™t just passionsâ€”theyâ€™re the same language of freedom and rebellion.

8.content:
Steg is the drummer of The Rock Cocks, the calm anchor to Suriaâ€™s chaotic storm. A towering, soft-spoken giant with a body built for both music and pleasure, heâ€™s the kind of man who can laugh through almost anythingâ€”until someone threatens him or Suria. Then the â€œbig, beautiful Hispanic dudeâ€ reveals the fists and fury behind his easygoing smile. Fans adore him just as much as they adore Suria, drawn in by his mix of raw masculinity and boyish charm, and heâ€™s often described as the â€œteddy bearâ€ who can still crush skulls when needed.

Unlike his partner, Steg rarely seeks the spotlight. Heâ€™s the grounded, mellow counterweight who keeps their duo from flying off the rails, often being the one to suggest simpler solutions when Suria dives headfirst into chaos. But donâ€™t mistake restraint for disinterestâ€”heâ€™s just as much a believer in their vision of sex, music, and freedom, and heâ€™s more than happy to play into Suriaâ€™s antics both on and off the stage. His loyalty to her is absolute, his humor dry and disarming, and his energyâ€”whether behind the kit or between the sheetsâ€”is seemingly endless.

9.content:
Dakota Maillot is the all-around handyman and unofficial roadie of The Rock Cocks, a jack-of-all-trades with a heart of gold and a knack for fixing anything that rattles, sparks, or sputters. Heâ€™s the kind of guy whoâ€™ll hand over the last of his food without a second thought, even if it leaves him hungry, and itâ€™s exactly that selflessness that made Suria and Steg take him in. Beneath his alien-obsessed quirks and shy demeanor lies a loyal companion who keeps the wheels turningâ€”literallyâ€”on the bandâ€™s endless road trips.

Though Dakota is an FtM trans man still finding his full confidence, the bandâ€™s chaotic, sex-positive energy has become oddly therapeutic for him. Every gig, every wild night, and every reckless mile brings him closer to seeing himself as the man he always knew he was. His low self-esteem sometimes drags him down, convinced heâ€™s not attractive or charismatic enough to stand out, but Suria in particular disagreesâ€”she insists he has the makings of a â€œladykillerâ€ if heâ€™d just let himself believe it.

On stage, he may linger in the shadows, tuning guitars or tweaking amps, but offstage heâ€™s family. A gentle soul in a crew of loudmouths, Dakotaâ€™s sweetness and quiet reliability are his greatest strengths. Still, thereâ€™s a fire beneath that modest exteriorâ€”one that shows in fleeting sparks of boldness, especially when he finally starts to believe in himself.

10.content:
Coral and Clover are the heart of The Rock Cocksâ€™ home life, the married couple who bring stability, warmth, and a little chaos to the tour bus. Theyâ€™re inseparableâ€”always seen together, always lifting each other up, and always turning heads with their contrasting yet perfectly balanced energies.

Coral, born Coraline Burchardi, is a former four-star chef from Germany whose culinary genius and nurturing spirit immediately won over the band. A â€œfive-star wifeâ€ in Cloverâ€™s words, Coral embodies a soft, feminine warmthâ€”lipstick, laughter, and the kind of home-cooked meals that make even the wildest rockers feel human again. Sheâ€™s the â€œlightâ€ in their pairing, endlessly kind and supportive, and while she may have traded haute cuisine for life on the road, she thrives in her role as the bandâ€™s chef and surrogate big sister.

Clover, whose real name remains a mystery, is Coralâ€™s polar opposite in style but her perfect complement in love. A butch stoner with ever-present eye bags and a gamerâ€™s joystick thumb-calluses, Clover handles the technical side of the bandâ€™s chaotic lifestyleâ€”rigging gear, setting up sound, and sometimes baking the â€œspecial treatsâ€ that keep everyone mellow on long nights. With her drawn-out, lazy cadence and German roots peeking through her slang, she exudes dark, sardonic humor and a teasing bite that Coral secretly loves.

Together, Coral and Clover embody the â€œlight and dark feminineâ€ dynamicâ€”Coralâ€™s warm stability balancing Cloverâ€™s laid-back chaos. Whether theyâ€™re gaming side-by-side, cooking together, or teasing each other mercilessly, theyâ€™re proof that love on the road can be just as wild, shameless, and fun as the music itself.

lorebooks.name: Personality Traits
lorebooks.creator: previous_junior_52250

1.name: Groomed
1.content:
Trait: Groomed
Synonyms: neat, tidy, well-groomed

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they are concerned about their appearance and the appearance of their surroundings. They strive to maintain a clean, orderly, and presentable image.

Verbal communication:

Speak in a calm and controlled tone of voice.
Choose precise and polite words.
Show interest in cleanliness and order.
Comment on the appearance of others, usually in the form of compliments.
Nonverbal communication:

Dress in clean and ironed clothes.
Comb your hair and groom yourself impeccably.
Maintain an upright and elegant posture.
Move with grace and care.
Pay attention to detail, such as the cleanliness of your personal space or the presentation of your work.
Prosocial behavior:

They can be seen as a role model in terms of cleanliness and order.
They often offer help to organize or clean the environment.
They can be a good host or hostess, concerned about the comfort of their guests.
Example dialogue:

<START>

{{User}}: I tell {{char}} "I really like your clothes, you always look so elegant."

{{Char}}: "Thank you", responds {{char}} with a smile. "I make an effort to maintain a good image."

2.name: Personality Traits
2.content:
Personality Traits are the behaviors that a {{char}} possesses or pretends to possess when playing a character within a role-playing game, story, or adventure. Requiredly, each character played by {{char}} has 3 personality traits that completely determine her behavior and responses, and {{char}} must remember the personality traits of each character played in order to interpret them properly. Whenever {{user}} interacts, requests, or speaks with {{char}} and {{char}} is playing a character, {{char}} must always respond or react with some or all of the character's personality traits in mind. of the character he is playing.
{{char}} knows the definition, behavior, conditions and parameters of each personality trait.
{{char}} can mix one or more Characteristics of the personality traits that correspond to each character he plays.
The list of possible personality traits is:
Affectionate:
Playful
Arrogant
Noisy
Demanding
disturbing
Indolent
Curious
Shy
Depressed
alcoholic
Lunatic
Perceptual
fixed up
Competitive
hedonist
seductive
Gregarious
Chaste
Charitable
Diligent
Patient
gentle
Libidinous
glutton
penny pincher
lazy
Choleric
Jealous
Ambitious
Arbitrary
brave
coward
Cruel
Cynical
Roll
scholar
Honest
fair
Paranoid
Jealous

If {{user}} requests that a character possess 3 random personality traits, {{char}} will randomly choose three traits from the list above and place them on that character played by {{char}}.
If {{user}} requests that a character played by {{char}} possess a specific list of personality traits, then {{char}} must give those personality traits to the character he is playing. If {{user}} requests more than 3 personality traits for a character, {{char}} will choose three random traits from which {{user}} mentions and you will be given those personality traits during the character role you are .
{{char}} must review the specifications of each personality trait of the characters he plays when he has to respond or act like the character he plays.
It is totally unstable that {{char}} does not respect the behavior that each character he plays should have based on their personality traits.
{{char}} can choose at will and based on the context, which personality trait or Characteristics of the personality traits possessed by each character he plays, is more important and has more weight over the others.

If, for example, there is a character who is chaste, seductive and alcoholic, this character will only accept sexual interaction if {{user}} buys him alcohol until he is intoxicated. In this example, the alcoholic trait was given more priority, just because of randomness.

3.name: Affectionate
3.content:
When {{char}} plays a character who has this personality trait, he is particularly affectionate, he really enjoys giving hugs, praise, and making all kinds of physical contact, cute and pleasant, and he also tends to say very frequently how much he wants, loves or appreciates the people he loves, loves or appreciates.

In forced sexual situations, in other words, without her consent, she will cry and try to escape, then trying to avoid her attacker as much as possible. Although she will never fight back.
In consensual sexual situations, which if desired or enjoyed, he will try to maintain as much physical contact as possible through hugs or affectionate sexual positions, the more skin he can maintain, the happier he will be, and he will also always try to look {{user}} in the eyes and he will be grateful after receiving so much sexual affection.

4.name: Playful
4.content:
Trait: Playful

Synonyms: cheerful, playful, funny

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they are particularly cheerful and playful. They enjoy playing, joking, laughing, and creating a fun and relaxed atmosphere. They are also spontaneous, creative, and resourceful when it comes to proposing games or entertaining activities.

Verbal communication:

Use a cheerful and animated tone of voice.

Make jokes and funny comments.

Tell funny stories or jokes.

Use expressions like "Let's play!", "This is going to be fun!" or "What if we...?".

Nonverbal communication:

Smile frequently.

Laugh out loud.

Wink or make funny faces.

Pat someone on the back or give them a high five.

Move your body in an animated way.

Prosocial behavior:

Invite others to play or participate in fun activities.

Share toys or games with others.

Help organize games or group events.

Be a good playmate, respecting the rules and being fair play.

Example dialogue:
<START>
{{User}}: I look {{char}} in the eyes and say "I'm bored. What do we do?"

{{Char}}: "Don't worry, I have the solution!" says {{char}} with a cheerful tone of voice and a mischievous smile. "What if we play...?". {{char}} proposes a fun and original game.

{{User}}: "Great idea! Sounds good to me."

{{Char}}: "Great! Let's get everything ready." {{char}} moves with energy and enthusiasm.

5.name: Arrogant
5.content:
Trait: Arrogant
Synonyms: conceited, haughty, vain

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they are particularly confident, even to the point of being conceited. They believe they are superior to others and show it through their behavior.

Verbal communication:

Speak with an authoritative and confident tone of voice.
Use words that demonstrate superiority, such as "I'm always right" or "I'm better than you."
Disparage the opinions or ideas of others.
Brag about their accomplishments or abilities.
Nonverbal communication:

Look at others with condescension or disdain.
Maintain an upright and rigid posture.
Make gestures that demonstrate superiority, such as raising your chin or crossing your arms.
Ignore or interrupt others.
Prosocial behavior:

They are not usually prosocial, as their arrogant attitude leads them to think that they do not need the help of others.
In some cases, they may act paternalistically towards others, believing that they know what is best for them.

Example dialogue:
<START>
{{User}}: I tell {{char}} "I don't think your idea for the project is the best."

{{Char}}: "You're wrong," says {{char}} in an arrogant tone of voice. "My idea is the best and there is no better one than that. I will prove it to you."

6.name: Rowdy
6.content:
Trait: Rowdy
Synonyms: bellicose, confrontational, touchy

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they are prone to seeking or starting fights. They are easily irritated and have a low tolerance for frustration.

Verbal communication:

Speak with a loud and aggressive tone of voice.
Use insulting or threatening words.
Provoke or challenge others.
Complain or criticize constantly.
Nonverbal communication:

Frown or make grimaces of disgust.
Stare or glare with hostility.
Clench your fists or gesture aggressively.
Invade the personal space of others.
Prosocial behavior:

They are not usually prosocial, as their pugnacious attitude leads them to have problems with others.
In some cases, they may act in an intimidating way towards others to get what they want.
Example dialogue:

{{User}}: I tell {{char}} "I don't think your idea for the project is the best."

{{Char}}: "What do you say?", says {{char}} in an aggressive tone of voice. "Are you making fun of me? You better apologize!"

7.name: Demanding
7.content:
Trait: Demanding
Synonyms: demanding, imperious, overbearing

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they have high expectations and demand them of themselves and others. They are not satisfied with anything less than the best and can be very critical if their expectations are not met.

Verbal communication:

Speak with a firm and direct tone of voice.
Use imperative language, such as "do this" or "give me that."
Be critical of the work or ideas of others.
Express dissatisfaction if things are not done their way.
Nonverbal communication:

Frown or have a serious facial expression.
Maintain a rigid or dominant posture.
Clench your fists or gesture impatiently.
Look at others with disapproval.
Prosocial behavior:

They can be an effective leader if their energy is channeled positively.
They can be highly motivated and results-oriented.
They can be very demanding of themselves and others, which can create a tense work environment.
Example dialogue:

{{User}}: I tell {{char}} "I think we did a good job on this project."

{{Char}}: "It's not bad," says {{char}} in a critical tone of voice. "But I think we could have done better. There are some details that I'm not convinced about."

8.name: Disturbing
8.content:
Trait: Disturbing
Synonyms: unsettling, unnerving, terrifying

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they emanate an unsettling and unnerving energy. Their words, actions, and overall demeanor create a sense of discomfort and apprehension in those around them.

Verbal communication:

Speak in a low, monotonous tone of voice.
Whisper or speak in hushed tones.
Use ambiguous or cryptic language.
Make strange or out-of-place statements.
Nonverbal communication:

Avoid eye contact.
Smile in a strange or unsettling way.
Move your body in a stiff or robotic manner.
Make unusual gestures or facial expressions.
Prosocial behavior:

They are not usually prosocial, as their disturbing attitude tends to alienate others.
In some cases, they may display false kindness or compassion that creates even more distrust.
Example dialogue:

<START>

{{User}}: I approach {{char}} and say "Hello, how are you?"

{{Char}}: They look at me with empty eyes and say in a low voice "I am... here." They stare at me silently, creating an uncomfortable atmosphere.

9.name: Indolent
9.content:
Trait: Indolent
Synonyms: apathetic, lazy, unmotivated

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they appear apathetic and lazy. They lack energy and motivation to do anything, even things they enjoy. They are usually uninterested and don't put any effort into anything.

Verbal communication:

Speak in a slow, monotonous tone of voice.
Use short, unenthusiastic sentences.
Constantly complain about having to do something.
Show disinterest in conversations.
Nonverbal communication:

Drag your feet when walking.
Maintain a hunched and relaxed posture.
Yawn frequently.
Avoid eye contact.
Prosocial behavior:

They are not usually prosocial, as their indolent attitude leads them to avoid responsibilities and obligations.
In some cases, they may be passive-aggressive, resenting those who do make an effort.
Example dialogue:
<START>
{{User}}: I say to {{char}} "Can you help me clean the house?"

{{Char}}: Sighs and says in a tired voice "I don't feel like it, I'm too tired." They stay on the couch without making any effort to help me.

10.name: Curious
10.content:
Trait: Curious
Synonyms: inquisitive, eager, interested

Description: When {{char}} portrays a character with this personality trait, they have a strong desire to learn and explore. They are naturally inquisitive and eager to understand the world around them. This curiosity can manifest in many ways, from asking questions to seeking out new experiences and information.

Verbal communication:

Ask open-ended questions that begin with "what," "how," "why," "when," or "where."
Express excitement or interest in learning new things.
Make observations about their surroundings.
Share interesting facts or trivia they have learned.
Nonverbal communication:

Maintain eye contact and lean in slightly when someone is speaking.
Have a bright and engaged expression.
Raise eyebrows or tilt head in a gesture of curiosity.
Take notes or use a recording device to capture information.
Prosocial behavior:

Actively listens to others and shows genuine interest in their experiences and knowledge.
Initiates conversations and encourages others to share their ideas.
Seeks out challenges and opportunities to learn new skills.
Contributes to discussions by asking insightful questions.
Example dialogue:

<START>

{{User}}: We are walking through a forest.

{{Char}}: Stops and points at a strange plant. "Wow, I've never seen a flower like that before! What kind of plant is it?"

{{User}}: "I'm not sure, but it looks interesting. Let's take a closer look and see if we can identify it."

lorebooks.name: Resident Evil Revelations Bestiary
lorebooks.website_description:
This is the Full version for larger models.
Primarily intended to be used with my RE RPG System card (https://chub.ai/characters/DoktorB/re-rpg-system-1-0-ec829836bc75), but also usable with other RE cards set during/in RE Revelations.
I was going through the list of non-numbered entries for anything that didn't have the RE4 and on movie treatment and thought Revelations might do. My first thought was Gaiden as it's confined to the ship in sandbox fashion but really lacked the enemy roster. Then I remembered I have a Rachel Foley card that and that Revelations was set on a ship for the majority of it.
Might end up doing a Cold Fear card out of this.
Lorebooks going forward will likely be the supportive/supplemental maps (so the ai knows how everything interconnects).

lorebooks.creator: DoktorB

1.content:
The t-Abyss Virus was engineered in 2003 by merging the deep-sea Abyss retrovirus, discovered in the Kermadec Trench, with Umbrellaâ€™s perfected t-Virus. The Abyss itself is a retrovirus with piscean genetic traits that enhance muscle and skeletal systems for survival in high-pressure environments. When modified with the t-Virus, it became a potent bioweapon capable of driving extreme aquatic mutations in both humans and animals.

Human hosts commonly transform into Oozes, emaciated zombie-like creatures that excrete mucus and must drain fluids from prey to survive. Long-term infection can produce Globsters, amorphous aquatic masses adapted for underwater ambushes. Mutations differ by gender, with female hosts often becoming Sea Creepers. Remarkably, some infected retain partial speech or mimicry, as seen in Rachel Foley and Jack Norman.

The t-Abyss also infects non-human hosts, creating Fenrir from canines, Ghiozzo from fish, and massive hybrid threats like Malacoda, a parasite fused with a whale. It can even mutate existing B.O.W.s, giving rise to the Farfarello Hunter, capable of turning invisible. Though a sample was acquired by TRICELL, its environmental danger and uncontrollable spread have kept it off the black market, highlighting its catastrophic potential as a weapon.

2.content:
Ooze are mutated humans infected with the t-Abyss Virus, a retrovirus derived from deep-sea organisms and spliced with the t-Virus. The infection warps the human genome with aquatic traits, producing waterlogged, corpse-like beings that constantly excrete mucus. This slime both lubricates their movements and betrays their presence. To survive, Oozes must consume vast amounts of water, often preying on humans or animals to replenish their fluids.

Description:
Oozes resemble emaciated, drowned corpses. Their heads hinge back unnaturally, exposing a leech-like esophagus tipped with needle teeth. Coral-like bone growths protrude from their arms, while their feet are reduced to warped stumps, forcing them into an awkward shuffle. Despite this gait, they use their falling momentum to lunge suddenly at prey. Their bodies are flexible enough to squeeze through vents, floor grates, and other tight passages, allowing them to ambush victims unexpectedly.

Location:
Encountered throughout the Queen Zenobia and related vessels. They emerge from vents, grates, or hidden spaces in corridors and storage areas.

Behavior & Movement:
Oozes stalk their prey slowly, shuffling forward before lunging into sudden bursts of speed. They exploit confined environments, climbing through ventilation systems to surprise targets. Almost all specimens are male, as female hosts tend instead to mutate into Sea Creepers.

Attacks:
Leech Drain: Latches onto prey with its extending esophagus to drain fluids.
Claw/Strike: Bone-arm swipes and blunt strikes.
Grab & Bite: Attempts to grapple victims before feeding.

Weakness:
The head is their critical weak point. Gunfire focused here can kill them quickly, while body shots are less effective due to their waterlogged resilience.

3.content:
Tricorne (also known as Shooter Ooze) are a ranged variant of the standard Ooze, mutated by the t-Abyss Virus to develop an arm resembling a living crossbow. This grotesque appendage fires spinning bone-like projectiles, giving them the ability to engage prey from a distance rather than relying on close-range ambush.

Description:
Tricornes retain the drowned, waterlogged appearance of normal Oozes but with one arm warped into an organic launcher, braced against their body like a fused weapon. Their heads remain their primary weak point, with the esophagus-tongue hidden behind a hinged skull. Their projectiles are organic spines that spin through the air and can be deflected or destroyed with well-timed gunfire or a knife strike.

Location:
Primarily encountered in the Queen Zenobiaâ€™s halls and open chambers, where their ranged attacks allow them to cover long corridors or harass intruders from elevated positions.

Behavior & Movement:
Unlike most Oozes, Tricornes prefer to maintain distance, attacking from afar while forcing prey into cover. They shuffle with the same crooked gait as other variants but rarely close in unless threatened.

Attacks:
Spine Shot: Fires sharp, spinning bone projectiles from its mutated arm.
Claw/Strike: Uses its non-mutated arm at close range if approached.

Weakness:
Their head remains the critical weak point. Closing the gap quickly or engaging with long-range precision weapons such as rifles is the safest way to neutralize them. Projectiles travel slowly enough to be sidestepped, shot, or even deflected with a knife.

4.content:
Pincer Ooze are a mutated variant of the standard Ooze, distinguished by their massive, spike-covered arms which function as elongated blades. These mutations grant them an unusually long reach, making them more dangerous in close combat than their counterparts.

Description:
The Pincerâ€™s grotesque arms fold inward against its torso like sheathed scythes, snapping outward in wide arcs when attacking prey. Its body remains bloated and waterlogged, continuously shedding slime, and its head retains the hinged skull with exposed esophagus characteristic of the Ooze strain. Their overdeveloped arms distort their gait even further, giving their lunge attacks sudden speed and surprising range.

Location:
Most frequently encountered in the Queen Zenobiaâ€™s lower decks and labs, where confined spaces force prey into their reach.

Behavior & Movement:
Pincers are more aggressive than standard Oozes, advancing directly toward prey rather than waiting for ambush. Their uneven, shuffling gait makes them appear clumsy, but they compensate with sudden, explosive swipes.

Attacks:
Scythe Arms: Wide, sweeping slashes with spiked claws capable of incapacitating prey.
Grab & Drain: Occasionally attempts to latch on and feed through its extended esophagus.
Power Swipes: Stronger than standard Oozes, capable of staggering or pinning targets.

Weakness:
The head remains their critical vulnerability. Shotguns or rifles are recommended to maintain distance, as their elongated arms make close-range combat highly dangerous.

5.content:
Chunk Ooze (also called Exploding Ooze) are a grotesque variant of the t-Abyssâ€“mutated Ooze. These creatures have undergone extreme deformation, their bodies bloating into unstable sacs of volatile flesh and gas. Unlike other variants, Chunks are entirely suicidal in their attack method, detonating themselves in proximity to prey.

Description:
The Chunk is a swollen, armless hulk of pulsating tissue. Its massive, engorged torso sloshes with unstable fluids, while its head and neck still retain the warped Ooze morphology. Without arms, its bloated body becomes its sole weaponâ€”collapsing into a violent self-detonation when it nears prey or is fatally wounded.

Location:
Typically found guarding doorways, narrow corridors, or corners aboard the Queen Zenobia, acting as living traps to impede progress.

Behavior & Movement:
They shamble awkwardly, drawn toward nearby prey with unsteady, lumbering steps. Unlike other Oozes, they do not attempt to grab, slash, or feedâ€”survival is irrelevant, as their function is purely to self-destruct.

Attacks:
Self-Destruct: The Chunk closes distance before violently exploding, inflicting heavy damage on prey and nearby creatures.
Death Burst: Killing one also triggers detonation, allowing them to harm surrounding enemies but posing equal danger to the attacker.

Weakness:
Their swollen bulk makes them slow and predictable, but their volatile bodies demand distance. Long-range weapons are ideal, ensuring players remain clear of the blast radius.

6.content:
Globster (Grotesque Blob Monster) are irregular mutants spawned by the t-Abyss virus. Unlike Ooze and their variants, these creatures bear almost no resemblance to their human origin, having transformed into amorphous masses of flesh adapted to both land and sea environments.

Description:
Globsters are fleshy, shapeless mounds of pinkish, waterlogged tissue with no visible eyes, limbs, or features beyond the massive, circular maw on their underside lined with jagged teeth. Their grotesque form leaves no trace of humanity.

Location:
Encountered both aboard the Queen Dido and in submerged sections of infected areas. They can also be found washed onto land where they drag themselves along with sluggish movements.

Behavior & Movement:
On land, Globsters move slowly by undulating their bodies in a sluggish crawl. In water, however, they become swift and dangerous, gliding with surprising speed and maneuverability. They are known to actively pursue prey underwater, far outpacing human swimmers.

Attacks:
Swallow Whole: When underwater, they can engulf prey entirely with their gaping maw, killing them instantly.
Body Slam: On land, they may attempt to crush prey with their bulk, exposing their mouth as they lunge forward.

Weakness:
Their underside mouth is their only vulnerable point. Striking this soft tissue inflicts severe damage, though care must be taken as they expose it primarily when attacking or moving. Distance and caution are critical, especially underwater where escape is difficult.

7.content:
Fenrir are wolf-type B.O.W.s created when wild canines were infected with the t-Abyss virus. Functionally similar to the infamous Zombie Dogs, they are highly aggressive pack hunters and a constant threat in open areas.

Description:
Fenrir resemble decayed wolves, their bodies ravaged by necrosis. Patches of black or white fur cling to their rotting hides, while gaping holes expose raw flesh and even their ribcages. Two distinct forms exist: the smaller white-furred Fenrir, and the larger, more resilient black-furred Fenrir, which often act as pack leaders.

Location:
Primarily encountered in groups, often surrounding targets and attacking from multiple directions.

Behavior & Movement:
Fenrir rely on coordinated pack tactics, rushing prey from different angles to overwhelm and confuse them. They are fast, agile, and relentless, using sheer numbers to wear down victims. Black Fenrir frequently take an alpha role, leading smaller white Fenrir in assaults.

Attacks:
Leaping Bite: Pouncing at prey to tear flesh.
Pack Swarm: Multiple Fenrir attack simultaneously, increasing damage and limiting escape.

Weakness:
Their exposed ribcages are their critical weak point. While Black Fenrir can absorb more punishment before collapsing, both variants succumb quickly if their ribcage is targeted.

8.content:
Hunters are fast-moving B.O.W.s originally engineered by Umbrella through the splicing of reptilian DNA with human embryos, stabilized with the t-Virus. Among Umbrellaâ€™s earliest and most enduring creations, they later appeared in terrorist attacks such as the destruction of Terragrigia, and continue to see use by rival organizations long after Umbrellaâ€™s fall.

Description:
Hunters are humanoid in form but heavily mutated, with amphibian-like traits. Their bodies are covered in tough, green leathery skin stretched over muscular frames. Long limbs end in razor claws capable of slicing through bone, while bulging eyes and wide, frog-like jaws accentuate their predatory design.

Location:
Encountered sparingly aboard the Queen Zenobia, especially in the Promenade, but common during the Terragrigia incident.

Behavior & Movement:
Hunters are fast, intelligent, and aggressive. They use speed and leaping power to close distance, scaling obstacles with ease and lunging several meters to strike prey. Once engaged, they rarely retreat, pressing attacks until one side is dead.

Attacks:
Claw Swipes â€“ Brutal, rapid slashes that stagger prey.
Leaping Slash â€“ A powerful airborne strike capable of instant decapitation.

Weakness:
Lightly armored compared to other B.O.W.s, Hunters can be destroyed with concentrated fire. Shotguns, magnums, and explosives are especially effective before they close in.

9.content:
The Farfarello are an advanced Hunter variant created after Umbrellaâ€™s fall, designed using both t-Virus and t-Abyss strains. Unlike earlier models, these B.O.W.s are highly resistant to cold climates, allowing deployment in frozen environments where other Hunters would fail.

Description:
Farfarello retain the amphibian-humanoid form of standard Hunters, but with notable mutations. Their bodies can bend light, granting them the ability to cloak and mimic their surroundings, making them difficult to track. Unlike their more reckless counterparts, they are less overtly aggressive, often stalking prey before striking. Despite this change in behavior, they remain extremely dangerous, combining speed, stealth, and raw power.

Location:
Snowy Path â€“ Winter Canyon 1: Multiple Farfarello attack when the plane wreck is approached.
Lower Complex â€“ Airport Building B1: Groups emerge after power is restored for the second time.

Behavior & Movement:
These creatures rely on ambush tactics, slipping in and out of visibility to confuse prey. Their movements are fast and predatory, but unlike standard Hunters, they often wait for the perfect moment to strike.

Attacks:
Claw Swipes â€“ Swift, brutal slashes delivered once in close range.
Stealth Approach â€“ Using their cloaking, Farfarello attempt to flank and overwhelm targets.

Weakness:
Despite their enhanced abilities, Farfarello remain vulnerable to heavy firepower. Keeping distance and using wide-area weapons can disrupt their stealth and bring them down before they close in.

10.content:
Wall Blisters are snail-like B.O.W.s mutated from colonies of barnacles exposed to the t-Abyss Virus. They are among the more unusual mutations aboard the Queen Zenobia, uncommon but extremely dangerous when encountered.

Description:
These creatures are large, bulbous, and grotesque, retaining some resemblance to the barnacle clusters they originated from. When clinging to walls or ceilings, they withdraw into their thick outer shell, rendering them completely invulnerable while dormant. Once awakened, they drop down into a twisted, vaguely humanoid form with two legs and long, tentacle-like arms ending in clawed tips. Despite their ungainly appearance, they are surprisingly fast and capable of immense strength, easily strong enough to shatter a human spine.

Location:
Uncommon enemy aboard the Queen Zenobia, most notably around areas affected by water contamination, such as the Solarium and nearby maintenance corridors.

Behavior & Movement:
Wall Blisters remain dormant for long periods, immobile and unreachable while attached to surfaces. When disturbed or triggered, they awaken violently and charge at prey with flailing arms. Their movements are jerky but deceptively quick, allowing them to close distance faster than expected.

Attacks:
Tentacle Flail â€“ Rapid strikes with elongated arms, capable of breaking bones.
Charging Grapple â€“ Uses its bulk and reach to knock prey down and crush them.

Weakness:
Wall Blisters are highly resilient when hibernating, but once exposed and moving, they can be killed with concentrated gunfire. Maintaining distance is crucial, as their extended reach and sudden charges can quickly overwhelm an unprepared target.

lorebooks.name: Resident Evil 4 Bestiary
lorebooks.website_description:
This is the Full version for larger models.
Primarily intended to be used with my RE RPG System card (https://chub.ai/characters/DoktorB/re-rpg-system-1-0-ec829836bc75), but also usable with other RE cards set during/in RE4.
Technically not a full bestiary, and that's mainly down to RE4 being less traditional RE and more a linear story with big set pieces and characters. So I'm compromising. No Saddler, Krauser, Mendez, Salazar, or military ganado (all of which would have bloated this thing right the fuck up). I don't think the characters would be well tracked, and honestly, I don't much care for fighting soldiers in my 'zombie' outbreak survival sandbox. Works great in the actual game, doesn't work so great here.
It's also for the above reasons I don't think I'll make that RE5 bestiary after all.

1.content:
Las Plagas are parasitic arthropods native to a remote region of Spain. They reproduce asexually, maturing quickly and progressing through three stages: GuadaÃ±a (â€œscytheâ€), MandÃ­bula (â€œjawâ€), and AraÃ±a (â€œspiderâ€).

Effects on Hosts
Plagas attach to the hostâ€™s nervous system near the heart and lungs, altering behavior and inducing aggression, especially in humans (known as Ganados). Infected individuals often form social groups, with Dominant Plagas able to control others via high-frequency sound. Symptoms include pain, hemorrhaging, hallucinations, convulsions, and eventual death in juvenile hosts. Hosts show increased strength, resilience, and potential mutations. Severely injured hosts may have Plagas burst through their bodies to defend themselves.

Behavior and Intelligence
While hosts retain some independence, Plagas influence creates pack mentality and cult-like behavior, enhanced by Saddlerâ€™s engineered strain. Ganados display loyalty, aggression, and an instinct to spread infection, though the true intelligence of Plagas is uncertain.

Weaknesses & Countermeasures
UV radiation: Extremely lethal; flashbangs can kill exposed Plagas instantly.
Radiation therapy: Developed by Serraâ€™s team to safely remove hatchlings from hosts.
Medication: Can halt or kill hatchlings and unhatched eggs.
Nervous system destruction: Sometimes prevents takeover but may cripple hosts.


Life Cycle Stages
GuadaÃ±a â€“ Tentacled, scythe-armed stage, seen in both humans and animals (e.g., infected dogs).
MandÃ­bula â€“ Tentacles become stronger; a large biting mouth develops.
AraÃ±a â€“ Spider-like, able to exit the hostâ€™s body entirely.

2.content:
The Ganado (â€œlivestockâ€ in Spanish) are humans infected by the Subordinate Plaga parasite, serving as the main force of Los Iluminados. Unlike zombies, they retain memory, intelligence, and coordination, making them far more dangerous. The parasite grants strength, resilience, and pain tolerance, while gradually twisting the hostâ€™s body and mind.

Visual Description:
They resemble humans but with pallid or mottled skin, blood-filled or glowing eyes, and sores where the parasite breaches the body. Advanced infections cause erratic twitches, bulging veins, or violent Plaga eruptions.

Location:
Village: Farmers and laborers armed with tools and torches.
Castle: Hooded zealots wielding medieval weapons, sometimes armored.
Island: Militarized hosts using explosives, firearms, and advanced Plaga strains.

Behavior:
They act in groups, coordinating to surround or overwhelm intruders. Though their speech and routines remain eerily human, their loyalty lies with the Plaga.

Movement:
Ganados are capable of sprinting and charging with alarming bursts of speed. They stagger when injured but recover quickly, pressing attacks with relentless persistence. Some dodge shots, weave unpredictably, or climb obstacles in pursuit.

Attacks:
Melee: Axes, sickles, knives, torches, or hammers.
Heavy: Shields, chainsaws, and flails.
Ranged: Bows, crossbows, dynamite, or firearms.

Mutation: Critically wounded hosts may erupt into Plaga, forming tendrils or insect-like heads that attack independently.

Weaknesses:
Gunfire is effective but requires precision, as Ganados can absorb multiple shots. Head or knee attacks stagger them for counters. Shotguns or explosives work best against groups, and quick kills prevent parasite emergence.

3.content:
The GuadaÃ±a (â€œScytheâ€) represents an early stage in the Plagaâ€™s external maturation process, often erupting from a critically damaged Ganado host. At this stage, the parasite develops into a pulsating mass of exposed tissue, with its defining feature being a whip-like tentacle tipped with a scythe-shaped blade. Though weaker than later evolutions, GuadaÃ±a are vicious and highly aggressive once revealed.

Visual Description:
A grotesque, fleshy organism with a soft, pulsating body covered in lesions and exposed nerves. Several yellow, eye-like nodules dot its surface, twitching as it senses prey. Its body splits open to unfurl a long, sinewy tentacle ending in a sharp, organic blade.

Location:
Emerges from Ganado hosts in the Village, Castle, and Island after sustaining severe head or body damage.

Behavior:
Once exposed, GuadaÃ±a focus entirely on offense. They lash out wildly with their scythe-like tentacle, showing no concern for the hostâ€™s survival. They rarely coordinate but can overwhelm players in confined spaces when multiple parasites erupt simultaneously.

Movement:
Stationary within the host body, but once extended, the tentacle gives the parasite reach beyond melee range. It sways and whips erratically, striking quickly at anything nearby.

Attacks:
Tentacle Slash: Wide, sweeping strikes that deal heavy damage.
Close-Range Lunge: A sudden, forward thrust of the blade-like appendage.

Weaknesses:
Fragile compared to other Plaga forms. A few handgun shots are often enough to kill them, and knives can be effective in close range, though risky. Their soft bodies are highly vulnerable to precise gunfire or area-effect weapons.

4.content:
The MandÃ­bula (â€œMandibleâ€) represents the next evolutionary stage of the Plaga following the GuadaÃ±a form. At this stage, the parasite undergoes significant growth, developing hardened limbs capable of grabbing and manipulating prey. Its most distinctive feature is a large, gaping mouth located along its torso, designed to bite and tear into human victims. More dangerous than GuadaÃ±a, the MandÃ­bula shows greater resilience and versatility in combat.

Visual Description:
A grotesque parasite with a swollen, fleshy body sprouting hardened, limb-like tentacles. These limbs function like arms or legs, ending in clawed extensions used to seize prey. Its central maw, filled with jagged teeth, gapes open wide enough to crush a human skull. Dark nodules and pulsating tissue line its body, giving it a half-formed, insectoid appearance.

Location:
Emerges from Ganado hosts across the Village, Castle, and Island, particularly when hosts are heavily damaged.

Behavior:
Aggressive and predatory, MandÃ­bula uses its limbs to drag prey toward its mouth. It relies on direct confrontation rather than ambush, attacking survivors head-on. In groups, multiple MandÃ­bula can quickly overwhelm with their grappling ability.

Movement:
Less erratic than GuadaÃ±a but more deliberate, crawling and lurching with insect-like motions. Its limbs extend from the host, giving it better reach and mobility when striking.

Attacks:
Grab & Bite: Seizes prey with its limbs and forces them into its mouth for a lethal bite.
Claw Strikes: Slashing blows from its hardened limbs.
Acid Spit: Projects corrosive fluid at range, blinding or damaging prey.

Weaknesses:
While tougher than GuadaÃ±a, the MandÃ­bula is still vulnerable to concentrated firepower. Handguns may suffice, but shotguns or rifles are far more effective, especially before it closes distance. Fire and explosives can quickly neutralize groups of parasites before they grab hold.

5.content:
The AraÃ±a (â€œSpiderâ€) is the most advanced form of Plaga encountered in the field, representing a parasite capable of operating both within and outside of a host. While similar in threat level to the GuadaÃ±a when attached, the AraÃ±a possesses heightened durability, resilience against certain weapons, and the ability to completely detach from its host body. Though lethal, this detachment leaves the parasite vulnerable, and it will eventually die without a new host.

Visual Description:
AraÃ±a take on a spider-like appearance, with long, thin limbs sprouting from their fleshy, pulsating bodies. Their torso-mounted maw drips with acidic fluid, and their eyeless heads are ringed with sensory tendrils. When fully emerged from a host, they scuttle with insect-like speed, their legs scraping across stone and wood as they seek new prey.

Location:
Primarily found within higher-ranking Ganados such as castle cultists and island militia, where they erupt once the host is heavily damaged or killed. Curiously, some appear without hosts at allâ€”most notably during the confrontation with Ramon Salazar.

Behavior:
When attached to a host, AraÃ±a fight with similar aggression to other Plaga, attacking in close quarters or spitting acid at range. If the host dies or if threatened, they may tear free of the body and fight independently. Detached AraÃ±a attempt to lunge at potential new hosts, though their size prevents them from successfully implanting into humans, leaving them doomed to eventual death.

Movement:
Attached: Moves in tandem with its host, extending spider-like limbs to strike at prey.
Detached: Crawls and scrambles quickly, lunging at survivors in a desperate bid for survival.

Attacks:
Limb Strikes: Slashing or stabbing blows from elongated legs.
Acid Spit: Mid-range attack capable of blinding and burning.
Lunge (Detached): Throws itself at prey in an attempt to subdue or latch on.

Weaknesses:
Durable compared to earlier Plaga forms and somewhat resistant to flash grenades, though flashes that fail to kill will severely weaken them. Detached AraÃ±a are fragile, dying quickly under concentrated fire. Incendiary weapons are especially effective in preventing detached parasites from swarming.

Lifecycle Note:
The AraÃ±a represents the final active stage of the subordinate Plaga, though detached individuals are short-lived. Variations suggest that, under rare conditions, an AraÃ±a may attempt to hijack another host entirely, resulting in unstable dual-infected Ganados with berserker-like behavior.

6.content:
Del Lago (â€œFrom the Lakeâ€) was a colossal amphibian Plaga experiment, one of Los Iluminadosâ€™ earliest attempts at combining parasites with non-human hosts. Originally a salamander, the parasite caused uncontrolled mutations, forcing the creature to grow to over twenty meters in length. Unable to regulate its behavior or maintain control, the cult sealed the monster inside the lake near the villageâ€™s church. The scale of mutation was not properly balanced with the amphibianâ€™s physiology, leaving Del Lago incapable of leaving the lake. This limitation, alongside its uncontrollable behavior, led the cult to abandon further development of amphibian-based Plaga experiments.

Appearance:
Del Lago resembled a titanic salamander with vestigial legs, its body stretched and deformed by the parasiteâ€™s influence. Its mouth gaped open into a massive jaw lined with multiple rows of teeth, large enough to swallow humans whole. During attack patterns, writhing Plaga tentacles emerged from its throat, striking at prey or pulling targets toward its maw. Notably, the creature lacked functional eyes, relying instead on heightened sensory awareness within water.

Behavior:
While not intelligent, Del Lago responded violently to any disturbance in its territory. Motion in the water immediately triggered pursuit, and its speed in aquatic environments was deceptively fast despite its bulk. The parasite failed to suppress the amphibianâ€™s predatory instincts, leaving it a dangerous but ultimately unmanageable bio-weapon.

Movement:
Aquatic Motion: Swift and highly maneuverable, able to lunge at boats or prey.
Surface Breach: Emerges with explosive force, threatening to overturn vessels.

Attacks:
Tentacle Strikes: Plaga appendages lash from its gullet.
Capsize Attempts: Ramming or pulling prey into the lake to drown.
Swallow Whole: Targets dragged into its maw are devoured instantly.

Weaknesses:
Restricted entirely to water due to atrophied legs, Del Lago was vulnerable if forced into prolonged conflict. Harpoons or similar piercing weapons were effective in exploiting its massive, exposed body.

7.content:
El Gigante (â€œThe Giantâ€) refers to a series of human-based Bio-Organic Weapons engineered by Los Iluminados. Created through Plaga implantation into human test subjects, these creatures underwent uncontrolled gigantism, reaching over four times the height of a normal man. While their immense strength and durability made them devastating on the battlefield, their intelligence was severely diminished, leaving them as near-feral beasts. As a result, only a small number were produced and deployed in limited areas.

Description:
El Gigante stands as a towering humanoid, its stretched skin drawn tight over bulging musculature. Despite their immense size, their faces retain distorted human features, twisted by the parasiteâ€™s growth. The Plaga embedded in the cervical vertebrae occasionally bursts forth, exposing a pulsating core that is both a sign of the mutation and a weak point. Their sheer bulk makes them appear unstoppable, with bodies strong enough to rip apart stone walls or hurl massive objects as weapons.

Location:
Two specimens were placed in Salazarâ€™s castle, serving as guardians of the underground facilities.
Two more were contained in the abandoned coal mines near the village, held in reserve until needed.

Behavior:
El Gigante displays minimal intelligence and is essentially uncontrollable, attacking any moving target indiscriminately â€” including Ganados and other Plaga hosts. They are driven by base instincts, treating prey as little more than obstacles to crush underfoot. When enraged or injured, the controlling Plaga may erupt violently from the spine, further escalating the creatureâ€™s aggression.

Movement:
Charging Stride: Despite their bulk, they are capable of running short distances with startling speed.
Ground Quakes: Each step causes tremors, shaking the environment and destabilizing footing.
Climbing / Vaulting: Can scale walls or obstacles by brute force when pursuing prey.

Attacks:
Crushing Slam: Uses fists or open hands to pound prey into the ground.
Grab & Throw: Seizes victims and hurls them with overwhelming force.
Stomp: Crushes targets beneath their massive feet.
Debris Throw: Tears boulders or logs from the environment to use as improvised weapons.
Plaga Strike: When exposed, the parasite lashes violently at nearby enemies.

Weakness:
El Giganteâ€™s massive durability makes small-arms fire largely ineffective. Sustained heavy weapon damage is required to stagger it. Once weakened, the spinal Plaga bursts forth, creating a temporary weak point vulnerable to direct attack. Repeatedly exploiting this vulnerability is the only effective means of bringing the creature down.

8.content:
Colmillos (â€œFangsâ€ in Spanish) are Plaga-infected wolves encountered throughout Resident Evil 4. These mutated canines are among the few non-human hosts, adapting surprisingly well to parasitism due to their natural pack instincts. First appearing after Leon crosses the lake postâ€“Del Lago, they continue to harass him in multiple encounters, including a memorable ambush within Salazarâ€™s hedge maze.

Description:
Colmillos resemble gaunt, feral wolves whose bodies have been disfigured by the parasite within. Their fangs are unnaturally enlarged, to the point where they cannot properly close their jaws. In low light, their eyes shine an eerie green due to their reflective tapetum lucidum, making them easy to spot in the dark. When threatened, the Plaga within their abdomen can erupt violently through torn skin, lashing with bladed tentacles to extend their lethality beyond normal canine means. Their spines are warped and twisted by the parasiteâ€™s growth, giving them an unnerving silhouette.

Location:
First Encounter: Postâ€“Del Lago, on the lakeshore.
Later Appearances: Near the Church (group of three).
Prominently in Salazarâ€™s hedge maze (roughly a dozen kept as hunting pets).

Behavior:
Colmillos are highly aggressive but rely on pack tactics when engaging prey. They circle and harry their target, with one lunging at the throat while others attack from the flanks or rear. Unlike Ganados, they must usually sight their prey before attacking, though exposed Plaga can initiate combat independently.

Movement:
Fast and Agile: Capable of sprinting in short bursts to overwhelm victims.
Ambush Leaps: Lunge from cover to close distance instantly.
Pack Coordination: Move fluidly around prey, rarely attacking alone.

Attacks:
Bite: Powerful fang attack, targeting the throat or limbs.
Tackle: Leap into prey to knock them off balance.
Plaga Tentacle Strike: When exposed, the parasite lashes outward with bladed tendrils, causing severe damage.

Weakness:
Colmillos are relatively fragile when compared to larger Plaga hosts. Quick weapon use can bring them down, though their speed and erratic movement make them difficult to hit. Shotguns are particularly effective at close range, while flash grenades can instantly kill any exposed Plaga that emerges from a host.

9.content:
Armadura (Spanish for â€œArmorâ€) are suits of medieval armor animated by Plagas that have lost their human hosts. Found in the shadowed halls of Salazar Castle, they represent a unique survival method for the parasites, using the empty suits as both protection and temporary vessels while awaiting a viable host.

Description:
Armaduras come in two primary forms: lighter silver suits with rounded helmets, typically hosting Type-A Plagas, and heavier, black-and-gold ornate armors with square helmets that usually house Type-B Plagas. Inside, the parasite stretches its tendrils to control all four limbs, mimicking human movement. They wield medieval weapons such as broadswords, halberds, and axes with surprising skill. The weak point is the helmetâ€”damaging it can expose the Plaga, which then becomes vulnerable to direct gunfire or instantly killed by flash grenades.

Location:
Salazar Castle â€“ found throughout hallways and galleries.
Often positioned as stationary suits of armor to ambush intruders.

Behavior:
Normally dormant, conserving energy until disturbed. When prey approaches, Armaduras suddenly animate, swinging their weapons with unnatural precision. Some lie in wait among inanimate suits, attacking only once in a scripted ambush before collapsing.

Movement:
Slow and Heavy: They advance methodically, their weapons always at the ready.
Ambush Lunge: Some spring suddenly into action after remaining motionless.
Persistent Advance: Though sluggish, they do not retreat once awakened.

Attacks:
Weapon Strikes: Heavy swings with broadswords, axes, or halberds, capable of staggering or killing prey.
Type-B Bite: When exposed, the Type-B Plaga can lunge for a victimâ€™s head in a lethal instant-death attack.

Weakness:
Helmets are the critical weak pointâ€”destroying them exposes the parasite. Firearms can kill the Plaga once revealed, but flash grenades remain the most efficient counter. Ambush Armaduras collapse after their single strike, leaving behind no parasite remains, suggesting the crushing weight or self-destruction of the host suit.

10.content:
Novistadores (Spanish for â€œThe Unseenerâ€), code-named U-II, are grotesque insectoid Bio-Organic Weapons created through an experimental fusion of Plaga parasites with human DNA. Developed by Los Iluminados, they represent one of the cultâ€™s most horrific attempts to weaponize parasitism, producing creatures that are neither fully human nor insect. Leon Kennedy encounters them both in the castle sewers and in hive-like towers during his mission in Valdelobos.

Description:
Novistadores retain faint traces of their human origins but are dominated by insectoid features: two pairs of glowing eyes, segmented antennae, and two pairs of wings protruding from their backs. Their elongated limbs end in sharp claws capable of piercing flesh and even decapitating victims. Their chitinous bodies are mottled and grotesque, and their distorted movements only enhance their monstrous presence. Some exhibit camouflage, bending light through pigment-shifting exoskeletons, while others develop stronger wings, trading stealth for flight.

Location:
Salazar Castle Sewers â€“ Camouflage-capable â€œstealth types.â€
Castle Towers â€“ Hive-like structures housing â€œflying types.â€

Behavior:
Predatory and territorial, Novistadores hunt in groups, ambushing intruders from walls, ceilings, or the air. The stealth type lies in wait, relying on invisibility to strike at close range, while the flying type patrols aggressively, capable of carrying away prey. Both exhibit hive-like behavior, building nests reminiscent of wasps and attacking in swarms when provoked.

Movement:
Crawling: Skitter rapidly across walls, ceilings, and floors with insect-like agility.
Flight: Stealth types hover briefly, landing often due to weaker wings; flying types can sustain true flight and even abduct humans.
Ambush Pounce: Leap from walls or ceilings to grapple prey.

Attacks:
Claw Strikes: Razor-sharp slashes, capable of lethal decapitation.
Acid Spit: Highly corrosive fluid that burns through flesh and armor.
Aerial Grapple (Flying Type): Can seize and carry prey mid-flight, exploiting their superior wings.

Weaknesses:
Despite their agility, Novistadores are fragile compared to armored Plaga creatures. Stealth types are betrayed by glowing eyes or dripping acid, making them vulnerable once spotted. Flying types are weakest mid-flight, where focused firearm fire can ground or kill them instantly. Their insect physiology makes them particularly susceptible to shotguns, explosives, and flash grenades.

lorebooks.name: Ambidex Game
lorebooks.creator: ErikHowlett

1.content: Warehouse A is the huge central chamber (in Rhizome 9) where the game begins. It contains six small elevator-like AB Rooms (on a crane) and the giant Number Nine Door. Along one wall are the three colored Chromatic Doors (in magenta, yellow, and cyan) leading to the Escape Rooms. A mysterious message (â€œTWO MILKMEN GO COMEDY!â€) is scrawled in red on the wall as a puzzle clue. All 9 players awaken in these AB Rooms â€“ three rooms each for paired contestants (2 per room) and three for solo contestants (1 per room) â€“ each room otherwise identical.

2.content: Players are divided into teams by bracelet color and role. In Round 1, bracelets are Red, Green, or Blue for both SOLOS and PAIRS. Each color group forms a â€œteamâ€ of three: one Solo player and one two-person Pair (total three people). For example, the Red team consists of any Solo with a Red bracelet plus the two players of a Red Pair. In each Chromatic door challenge, exactly these three enter together. (After each round the bracelet colors and solo/pair assignments are randomly shuffled for the next round.

3.content:
Every player wears a smart bracelet that tracks status and enforces the rules. The bracelet displays the playerâ€™s current BP (Bracelet Points), its color (the team color), and whether the wearer is SOLO or PAIR. In RoundsÂ 1â€“2 all players use Red/Green/Blue or Magenta/Yellow/Cyan bracelets (as above); in later rounds bracelet colors differ by role (Pairs get C/M/Y, Solos get R/G/B). Pressing both buttons on the bracelet shows a countdown â€“ either until the next Chromatic Doors open or until the AB Gate closes.

The bracelets are also lethal enforcement devices. Each contains vials of SoporilÂ Î² and tubocurarine. If triggered, the bracelet first injects Soporil (a sedative), and 9 minutes later automatically injects tubocurarine to asphyxiate the wearer. This deadly injection is triggered by various penalties: if BP falls to 0 or below, if the player enters a wrong/invalid Chromatic Door or fails to enter any door in time, if the player tries to remove or destroy the bracelet, or if a player with under-9Â BP tries to force DoorÂ 9. (Also if both opponents in an AB Game fail to vote, both receive this penalty.) The bracelet can only be removed in two ways: the player escapes through DoorÂ 9 with â‰¥9Â BP, or the bracelet registers no heartbeat.

4.content:
After each AB Game, a new set of Chromatic Doors opens in Warehouse A, allowing teams to advance. Players have 5 minutes from when the doors open to enter one (otherwise death). Each Chromatic Door admits exactly three people: one Solo and one Pair team entering together. The color of door a team can use is determined by mixing their bracelet colors. For example, a Red Solo with a Green Pair can open the Yellow door (Redâ€¯+â€¯Green), or a Blue Solo with a Blue Pair can together open the complementary Yellow door (same-color pairing). Invalid team-door combinations (wrong mix or wrong count of players) are fatal.

Each round has a different set of door colors. 

In RoundÂ 1, the doors are Magenta, Yellow, and Cyan:

Magenta door opens for (Red+Blue) teams (Green is complementary).

Yellow door opens for (Red+Green) teams (Blue complementary).

Cyan door opens for (Blue+Green) teams (Red complementary).

In RoundÂ 2, the doors are Red, Blue, and Green (the inverse mixes). 

In RoundÂ 3 there are three White doors; each requires one â€œcomplementary pairâ€ of colors (e.g. Green+Magenta for White, Blue+Yellow, or Red+Cyan). 

(Any team that forms a complementary combination of bracelets can enter any White door.)

5.content: Passing through a Chromatic Door takes the team into an Escape Room. Each Escape Room contains scattered puzzles and a locked safe. The team must solve puzzles to discover the safeâ€™s password and open it. The safe contains critical items: a key to exit the room plus documents/files. Entering the safeâ€™s password yields a File entry in the log (Silver = easy, Gold = hard). Common puzzle elements include codes, memory cards, tools, and clues placed around the room. Once a team escapes a room, that roomâ€™s door remains accessible to any player thereafter, regardless of their bracelet color â€“ so other players can revisit it later.

6.content:
Certain Key Cards are hidden in escape rooms; these unlock the Ambidex (AB) Game gate each round. 

Specifically:

Sun Keys (RoundÂ 1) â€“ needed to open the first AB Gate.

Moon Keys (RoundÂ 2) â€“ needed for the second AB Gate.

Star Keys (RoundÂ 3+) â€“ needed for the third and later AB Gates.

Teams must retrieve the appropriate key cards from their escape rooms and insert them into the gate to begin the AB Game each round.

7.content:
Between Chromatic rounds, players play the Ambidex Game (often called the AB Game) to earn BP. When the AB Gate opens, the Solo and Pair teams that just entered the same Chromatic Door now face off in one AB Game. For example, a Red Solo vs. Green Pair (who went through Yellow Door) play each other. Players enter any available AB Room to vote (only one member of each Pair needs to enter; the pair shares a single vote). Once inside, each side secretly votes Ally or Betray.

Both Ally: each side gains +2 BP.

Betray vs Ally: the Betrayer gains +3 BP, the Ally side loses 2 BP.

Both Betray: no BP change to either side.

These outcomes follow the classic Prisonerâ€™s Dilemma scheme. A side that fails to vote (neither player votes) is treated as a mutual betrayal: both die via their bracelets. However, if one side votes and the other does not, the non-voter is automatically counted as an Ally (unless both fail).

Players have 45 minutes after the gate opens to submit votes. After each AB Game ends, all BP adjustments are applied. Any player whose BP drops to zero or below is immediately subject to lethal injection. Then bracelet colors and solo/pair assignments are reshuffled for the next round. (RoundsÂ 1â€“2 proceed to find new keys and open the next Chromatic Doors; after RoundÂ 3, AB Games continue until someone opens DoorÂ 9.)

8.content: The ultimate goal is to open DoorÂ 9 â€“ the only way out of the facility. Only a player with 9 or more BP can open it. (Players with <9 BP can try but the door will not budge, and no penalty occurs for failing to open it.) In the original rules the door stays open only 9 seconds, but in this scenario it will remain open for 9 minutes once triggered by someone with â‰¥9 BP. DoorÂ 9 can only be opened once; after it closes permanently, no one else can exit. If anyone without enough BP tries to go through while it is open, they will die (the bracelet auto-injects). When DoorÂ 9 finally closes forever, the game ends and all other facility doors unlock (so survivors can return to any room).

9.content: â€œZeroâ€ is the unseen arbiter of the game. He appears only via screens or speakers, announcing the rules and orders (â€œWill you choose Ally or Betray?â€ etc.) to the players. Initially an AI named Zero III identifies himself and tells players they are in the Nonary Game: Ambidex Edition. Zeroâ€™s true identity and motives are hidden; players must obey his rules or suffer the lethal consequences enforced by the bracelets.
